Forms are an important element of a website (especially one with all sorts of dynamic content). A set of functions has been written to ease the creation of form elements which provide default value selection, data integrity and error handling.

Creating form elements

A set of functions has been defined to create form elements for you which make it easy to have fill in default values and to provide some basic control over the behavior of the element. These functions are:

FunctionDescription
#Form::input_buttonCreate a button element
#Form::input_checkboxCreate a checkbox element
#Form::input_hiddenCreate a hidden element
#Form::input_passwordCreate a password element
#Form::input_radioCreate a radio element
#Form::input_submitCreata a submit button element
#Form::input_textCreate a text element
#Form::select_fieldCreate a combobox element
#Form::textarea_fieldCreate a textarea element

All these functions have one thing in common. The support any number of additional arguments besides their usual arguments. These arguments are interpreted as key/value pairs. These key/value pairs are then added as key="value" attributes to the element, with exception of a few special additional arguments specified below:

KeyValueDescriptionApplies to
fieldany stringEvery element has a name but this name does not always correspond to the key used in the elements default data. This parameter sets the key to be used in the dataAll elements
noposttrue or falseThis specifies whether or not to get the default value for the element from the POST data. By default nopost is false and thus the POST data is used as the default value when available. Set it to true if you don't want this behaviorAll elements
formatterA callback function nameThis parameter specifies a formatter function to be used to format the default data to be displayed in the element.All elements except #Form::select_field
defaultthe value of the default item to select The item in a select field which is initially selected #Form::select_field

Form data validation

The #Form::check_values can be used to validate (and format) the data submitted by the form. It will return the valid data (optionally formatted) as an associative array. It will also provide an array with all the names of the invalid data.

Handling errors

When errors occurred during the data validation you usually want to display these errors. In most cases all form elements have labels which tell the user what data that element represents. The function #Form::label can be used to display such a label. When the errors from the data validation process are passed on to this function it will mark the label if an error occurred in the data represented by the label.
